RespiratorySystem.name: Common Cold
RespiratorySystem.description: A mild, self-limited upper respiratory tract viral infection, common in children due to immature immunity
etiopathogenesis: Caused by rhinoviruses (most common), coronaviruses, adenoviruses, RSV, etc.
Spread via droplets, direct contact, and fomites
Affects nasal mucosa, pharynx, sinuses
mode_of_transmission: Peak incidence: preschool children in winter months
RespiratorySystem.infective_period: 1 day before symptoms start to 5–7 days after onset; Can be longer in young children
clinical_features: Sore throat, dry cough, low-grade fever
Nasal discharge may become thicker (not always bacterial)
treatment: Avoid antibiotics unless secondary bacterial infection suspected
prevention: Breastfeeding in infants for passive immunity

RespiratorySystem.name: Pharyngotonsillar Infection
RespiratorySystem.description: Inflammation of the pharynx and/or tonsils, commonly viral but may be bacterial (notably Group A Streptococcus)
etiopathogenesis: Viral causes (most common): Adenovirus, rhinovirus, influenza, EBV
Bacterial causes: Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus (GAS) = Strep throat
Spread via respiratory droplets and direct contact
infective_period: Streptococcal: Until 24 hours after antibiotic initiation

Bacterial (GAS): Enlarged tender anterior cervical lymph nodes

diagnosis: Clinical: Centor criteria for GAS suspicion
Throat swab: Rapid antigen detection test (RADT) or culture
CBC: ↑ leukocytes in bacterial; lymphocytosis in viral/EBV
Monospot test for EBV (if suspect mono)

Viral: Supportive care only: hydration, analgesics, rest
Bacterial (GAS): For penicillin allergy: Azithromycin or Cephalexin

prevention: Complete antibiotic course in bacterial cases to prevent complications

RespiratorySystem.name: Croup (Laryngotracheobronchitis)
RespiratorySystem.description: A viral infection of the upper airway (larynx + trachea), leading to narrowing and classic barking cough and stridor
etiopathogenesis: Cause: Mostly Parainfluenza virus type 1, also RSV, Influenza, Adenovirus
Pathology: Viral inflammation → subglottic edema → airway narrowing
Peak age: 6 months to 3 years
mode_of_transmission: Airborne droplets and contact with respiratory secretions
RespiratorySystem.infective_period: Few days before to a week after symptoms start
clinical_features: Worse at night, may wake child suddenly
Symptoms usually peak on day 2–3 and resolve by 5–7 days

differential_diagnosis.clue: Rapid onset, high fever, drooling, toxic child

diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis mostly
Neck X-ray: shows "Steeple sign" (subglottic narrowing)
Pulse oximetry to assess hypoxia in severe cases

Moderate to severe (stridor at rest or r: Dexamethasone IV/IM if not tolerating oral
Observe for at least 2 hours post-nebulization

prevention: Hand hygiene, avoid contact with sick children
Influenza vaccination may reduce related episodes

RespiratorySystem.name: Acute Bronchitis
RespiratorySystem.description: A self-limited inflammation of the bronchi, usually viral, resulting in persistent cough in children
etiopathogenesis: Cause: Viruses: Influenza, Parainfluenza, RSV, Adenovirus
Rarely Mycoplasma pneumoniae in older children
Inflammation of bronchial mucosa → edema, mucus → cough
mode_of_transmission: Droplets and direct contact with respiratory secretions
Common after or during a cold or URTI
RespiratorySystem.infective_period: Typically, during the first week of symptoms
clinical_features: No signs of pneumonia (no crepitations, no respiratory distress)
Duration: cough may persist for 2–3 weeks
diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis
Chest X-ray if diagnosis is uncertain or prolonged cough
CBC may show mild leukocytosis or normal
Rule out pneumonia or asthma if not improving
treatment: Antibiotics not recommended (unless suspected bacterial infection)
Bronchodilators if wheezing or underlying asthma

RespiratorySystem.name: Acute Bronchiolitis
RespiratorySystem.description: A common viral lower respiratory tract infection in infants, characterized by inflammation of the bronchioles leading to wheezing and respiratory distress
etiopathogenesis: Most common cause: Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV)
Other causes: Parainfluenza, Influenza, Adenovirus, Human Metapneumovirus
Affects children <2 years, especially <6 months
Virus → bronchiolar epithelial damage → mucus, edema, airway narrowing
mode_of_transmission: Highly contagious, especially in daycare settings
RespiratorySystem.infective_period: From 1–2 days before symptoms to 1–2 weeks after
clinical_features: Starts as URI (cold, mild fever, runny nose)
Symptoms peak by day 3–5, recover in 7–10 days

differential_diagnosis.clues: Sudden onset, localized wheeze, no fever

diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis in most cases
Pulse oximetry to assess oxygen saturation
Chest X-ray: hyperinflation, patchy atelectasis (not routine)
RSV antigen test (nasopharyngeal aspirate) – optional, for high-risk settings
treatment: Hydration and feeding support (IV/NG if needed)
Saline nasal drops + suction for nasal blockage
No routine use of bronchodilators, steroids, or antibiotics
Hospitalize if: Severe distress, Poor feeding, Hypoxia, High-risk infant
complications: Later development of recurrent wheezing/asthma-like episodes
prevention: Palivizumab (monoclonal antibody) in high-risk infants (e.g., prematurity, CHD) – monthly during RSV season

RespiratorySystem.name: Pneumonia
RespiratorySystem.description: Inflammation of lung parenchyma, usually infectious, leading to consolidation and impaired gas exchange

common_causes_by_age.pathogens: GBS, E. coli, Klebsiella, Chlamydia, RSV
Viruses (RSV, Adenovirus, Influenza), S. pneumoniae, H. influenzae

etiopathogenesis.mechanism: Pathogens enter alveoli → inflammation → exudate → consolidation, poor oxygenation

RespiratorySystem.infective_period: During symptomatic phase, especially in viral cases
diagnosis: Clinical signs: Tachypnea, crepitations, indrawing
Chest X-ray: lobar or patchy consolidation
CBC: neutrophilia in bacterial; lymphocytosis in viral
Blood culture, sputum culture in severe/complicated cases

Inpatient (moderate-severe): IV Ceftriaxone in suspected S. pneumoniae

prevention: Good nutrition, hygiene, avoiding smoke exposure
Early treatment of URTI to prevent progression

RespiratorySystem.name: Pleural Effusion
RespiratorySystem.description: Abnormal accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, often secondary to infection, malignancy, or systemic disease

types: Tubercular: chronic effusion in TB-endemic regions
Transudate: due to systemic causes (e.g., nephrotic syndrome, heart failure)

mode_of_transmission: Often a complication of primary infections (e.g., pneumonia, TB)
RespiratorySystem.incubation_period: Variable; develops during or after respiratory infection
RespiratorySystem.infective_period: Depends on underlying infection (e.g., pneumonia, TB)
clinical_features: Decreased chest expansion on affected side

differential_diagnosis.clues: Bilateral effusions, signs of volume overload

diagnosis: Chest X-ray: homogenous opacity, obliteration of costophrenic angle
Ultrasound chest: detects small effusions, guides aspiration
Pleural fluid analysis: Appearance, protein, LDH; Gram stain, culture, AFB, ADA
CBC, ESR, Mantoux test (for TB)
treatment: Treat underlying cause: Pneumonia → antibiotics; TB → ATT; Heart failure → diuretics
Chest tube drainage if: Purulent fluid (empyema) or Large symptomatic effusion
prevention: Early and adequate treatment of pneumonia, TB
Nutritional support and hygiene in high-risk children

RespiratorySystem.name: Empyema Thoracis
RespiratorySystem.description: A collection of pus in the pleural cavity, usually as a complication of pneumonia or pleural effusion
etiopathogenesis: Usually secondary to bacterial pneumonia
Common organisms: Streptococcus pneumoniae, Staphylococcus aureus (incl. MRSA), Mycobacterium tuberculosis
Stages:
1. Exudative (serous fluid)
2. Fibrinopurulent (pus, septations)
3. Organizing (fibrous thickening)
mode_of_transmission: Results from spread of infection to pleural space
RespiratorySystem.incubation_period: Develops over days to weeks during or after pneumonia
RespiratorySystem.infective_period: Active during pneumonia or TB phase, not once closed
clinical_features: Reduced chest movement, dullness on percussion
Intercostal bulge may be present in chronic cases

differential_diagnosis.differentiating_clues: Localized cavity, not in pleural space

diagnosis: Chest X-ray: dense homogenous opacity, no air bronchogram
Ultrasound chest: septations, fluid loculations
Diagnostic thoracentesis: Thick frank pus, ↑ protein & LDH, ↓ glucose; Gram stain, culture, AFB
CBC: leukocytosis, ↑ CRP/ESR
Blood culture may be positive
treatment: IV antibiotics: Empirical: Ceftriaxone + Vancomycin; Modify based on culture
Surgical decortication (if no response after 1–2 weeks)
complications: Growth retardation in chronic untreated cases

RespiratorySystem.name: Pneumothorax
RespiratorySystem.description: Presence of air in the pleural space, causing partial or complete lung collapse

types: Spontaneous: Primary (no underlying disease), Secondary (lung disease)
Tension pneumothorax: air enters but cannot escape → emergency

mode_of_transmission: Results from trauma or lung pathology
clinical_features: Decreased breath sounds on affected side
Tension pneumothorax features: Severe distress, Tracheal shift, Hypotension, cyanosis
diagnosis: Chest X-ray: Visible pleural line, absent lung markings, collapsed lung
Ultrasound chest: absence of lung sliding sign
ABG: may show hypoxia

Moderate/large or symptomatic: Needle aspiration or intercostal chest drain (ICD)
Tension pneumothorax (EMERGENCY): Immediate needle decompression (2nd ICS, midclavicular line)

prevention: Prompt treatment of underlying respiratory illnesses

RespiratorySystem.name: Asthma
RespiratorySystem.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder of the airways leading to reversible airway obstruction, bronchospasm, and hyperresponsiveness

triggers: Allergens (dust, pollen), exercise, infections, smoke, strong odors, weather change, emotional stress
types: Mild, Moderate, Severe Persistent asthma – based on frequency of symptoms & lung function

RespiratorySystem.mode_of_transmission: Non-infectious, but viral URTIs often trigger episodes
clinical_features: Recurrent episodes of: Wheezing, Cough (worse at night/early morning), Shortness of breath, Chest tightness
Prolonged expiration, use of accessory muscles in severe cases

differential_diagnosis.clues: Chronic symptoms, failure to thrive, steatorrhea

diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on recurrent symptoms
Pulmonary function test (PFT) in children >5 yrs: ↓ FEV₁, improved post-bronchodilator
Peak Expiratory Flow Rate (PEFR) variability ≥20%
Chest X-ray: hyperinflation (during acute attack)
Allergy testing may help identify triggers

Acute Attack (Mild to Moderate): Inhaled short-acting β2 agonist (SABA): Salbutamol via MDI/spacer or nebulizer
Oral corticosteroids (e.g., Prednisolone 1–2 mg/kg for 3–5 days)
Severe Attack: IV magnesium sulfate if not responding
Long-term Control: Add LABA, leukotriene receptor antagonists (e.g., montelukast) if needed

complications: Poor growth due to repeated steroid use or chronic disease
School absenteeism, reduced quality of life
prevention_education: Educate caregivers on inhaler technique, symptoms, action plan
Use of asthma action plan for home management

RespiratorySystem.name: Emphysema
RespiratorySystem.description: Abnormal, irreversible dilatation and destruction of alveoli leading to impaired gas exchange (rare in children)
etiopathogenesis: Destruction of alveolar walls → loss of surface area for gas exchange
Loss of elastic recoil → air trapping
Types:
Congenital lobar emphysema (CLE) – overinflated lobe in neonates/infants
Secondary emphysema – due to: Severe asthma, Cystic fibrosis, α₁-antitrypsin deficiency, Bronchopulmonary dysplasia

Congenital Lobar Emphysema: Decreased breath sounds on affected side

differential_diagnosis.clues: Sudden onset, hyperresonant, absent breath sounds

diagnosis: Chest X-ray: Overinflated lung fields, Hyperlucency, flattened diaphragm, Mediastinal shift (in CLE)
CT scan chest: confirms diagnosis, detects bullae
Pulmonary function test (PFT): ↓ FEV₁, ↑ residual volume
α₁-antitrypsin levels: if suspected deficiency

Congenital Lobar Emphysema: Surgical lobectomy for severe or progressive distress

prevention: Early diagnosis and management of chronic lung diseases
Genetic counseling if α₁-antitrypsin deficiency is present
